corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of compilation audio tape recordings; concert recordings from 1954-1969; and dubs of bluegrass radio programs, singles, and LPs.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Accruals from Neil Rosenberg were received in 2014, 2019, and 2023. Future accruals are expected.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Physical materials in the Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection were processed by Maya Lerman and Marcia K. Segal between 2013-2022.

Digital content from DVDs was ripped by AFC staff in 2013 and the carriers deaccessioned. Files from the DVDs and a separate file transfer were processed by Farrah Cundiff in 2024 into an archival information package (AIP): afc2002009_dc001. Derivatives created by the donor were retained. System files were removed. Some content which corresponded to physical source recordings in the
Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection (AFC 2011/011)
, was separated to be processed in that collection. Otherwise, folder directories arranged by the donor were retained.

separatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Tapes with original numbers 12-15, 106, and 281-290 were acquired as part of the Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection (AFC 2011/011).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

altformavail.head: Alternate Formats
altformavail.p:
Selected sound recordings in the Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection exist in both analog and digitized formats. Digitized versions were created by donor Brian Miksis as part of his "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive" digital project. Miksis edited them to enhance quality, and he created derivatives: high-resolution (aif or wav), medium-resolution CD pre-tagged (aif), and low-resolution mp3 pre-tagged (mp3) versions. See
notes in Series 3
.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Neil V. Rosenberg Bluegrass music collection, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Neil V. Rosenberg
bioghist.p:
Neil V. Rosenberg (born 1939, in Seattle, Washington), grew up in Olympia, Washington, Los Alamos, New Mexico, and Berkeley, California. From age seven he studied violin, and later studied guitar and voice. His studies at Oberlin College (where he earned a B.A. in history) overlapped with his time as co-founder of the Redwood Canyon Ramblers. After graduation from Oberlin he attended Indiana University (where he earned his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in folklore). Throughout this time he remained active as a musician and, with the banjo as his primary musical instrument, he played at the Brown County Jamboree in the early 1960s. His writing career from the mid-1960s has focused on bluegrass music history, and he has written critically acclaimed books including
Bluegrass: A History
(1985; revised 2005),
Bluegrass Odyssey: A Documentary in Pictures and Words, 1966-86
(2001), and
Bluegrass Generation: A Memoir
(2018), as well as album liner notes and scholarly articles. His teaching career includes work at Indiana University (1966-1968) and Memorial University of Newfoundland (1968-2004). In Canada, as in the U.S., Rosenberg developed, founded, and mentored various musical endeavors: co-founder of the bluegrass band Crooked Stovepipe; host of a weekly bluegrass music show (broadcast on radio station CKIX-FM (St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada); and numerous other achievements that served to draw and maintain a lively interest in the genre and history of bluegrass music. In 2014, he was inducted into the Bluegrass Hall of Fame.

bioghist.head: Brian Miksis
bioghist.p:
Brian Miksis, a sound mixer with over 15 years of experience, digitized the recordings in this collection, and provided detailed metadata on the process and result. He has co-researched and produced an early history of Jerry Garcia's bluegrass roots, entitled
Before the Dead
(2018), and authored
"An introduction to the Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive"
.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of compilation audio tape recordings made from dubs of bluegrass 78 rpm discs, 45 rpm discs, LPs, radio airchecks, concert recordings, and interviews, in a series titled Bluegrass Anthology, some recordings are undated, some are dated 1948-1964. Plus a numerical series of concert recordings made by Neil V. Rosenberg and others at the Bean Blossom Festival, Mockingbird Hill Park, Club 47, Oberlin College, University of Illinois, Purdue University, in Berkeley, California; in Bloomington, Indiana, and other locations, from 1954-1969; plus various dubs of bluegrass radio programs, singles, and LPs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection is organized in three series:

item.ref: Series 1. Tennessee-Tombigbee Folklife Survey and related materials

arrangement.p: Filepaths and digital files can be found in afc2002009_dc001. Please see the AFC reference staff for access.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Tennessee-Tombigbee Folklife Survey and related materials

scopecontent.p: Materials associated with efforts to create a fieldwork project to document the socio-economic impact of the creation of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway.

Collected for Rosenberg's report on the impact of Federal public works projects on the folk culture of America and the ways in which the Archeological and Historic Preservation Act (Public Law 93-291) can mitigate that impact of July 16, 1979. Report is in #9. Approximately 200 pages. Original folder number: 1. See
Box-Folder 1/2
for the balance of this folder's contents. No original folder heading.

Includes Julia Butler Hansen correspondence which came to the attention of Ralph Rinzler in 1979, and who referred to it at the AFC Board meeting that led to the cancellation of the project. Approximately 20 pages. Original folder number: 2.
Notes on talk with Alan Jabbour. 1 page. Original folder number: 4.
Mainly from 1979 boondoggle scandal. 9 items. Original folder number: 5.

did.physdesc: 5 black and white photos : 5 in. x 8 in.

scopecontent.p: Includes photos of the following individuals: Archie Green (in the wide shot, with his back to the camera) talking to the board, and in the one vertical shot. Benny Keel (archeologist, and government official, with dark hair and a moustache), Jane Sapp (woman), and Wayland Hand (finger in the air). According to Carl, subsequent to this meeting Alan Jabbour decided not to proceed with the project.

did.didnote: Digital files are located in afc2002009_dc001. Please see the AFC reference staff for access.

scopecontent.p: Neil Rosenberg collected sound recordings for his own research, building a reference library of live recordings and studio recordings (including dubs of commercial recordings). Some of the recordings were sent to him as a gift or by request; the sources are noted if known.

Brian Miksis digitized selected sound recordings and documentation, making high-resolution and lower-resolution surrogates. See
Digital surrogates of selected recordings in Series 3
. Song lists and production notes listed below are his own, compiled from his own research, observations while digitizing the recordings, and guidance from Neil Rosenberg, especially when the pitch needed adjustment to restore the audio quality.

The archivist used a combination of Rosenberg's detailed inventories and information on tape boxes to create a list of contents per recording, and made additions and corrections based on further research. In addition, Rosenberg provided subsequent edits to the information. The documentation includes the names of those people who gave him tapes, identified in this finding aid as the "source." According to Rosenberg's documentation, items assigned the IDs SR256, SR268, and SR278 were deaccessioned from his collection prior to its arrival at AFC. He also noted that the ID SR262 was inadvertently not assigned to any recording, and the recording with the ID SR024 was loaned to someone but not returned.

The original inventory includes tapes numbered 12-15, 106, 281-290. These are part of the
Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection (AFC 2011/011)
.

Contents of Rosenberg's three-binder comprehensive, item-level inventory of recordings in his collection, which includes original and photocopied documentation about songs, performers, venues, locations, and dates.

Folders 1 of 14 folders. See

did.unittitle:
Hoot at Oberlin College; Lorain County String Band; Plum Creek Boys,
spring 1959
,
February 27, 1960
,
May 16 and 31, 1959
,
April 1960

scopecontent.p: According to Rosenberg, this tape is a compilation of dubs of tapes from his collection and tapes in the collections of other people.

The tracks from the hoot were dubbed from an original set of two tapes. The recordist Nancy Decker made multiple copies, and made copies to order.
SR018
and
SR019
have most of the hoot.

Lorain County String Band personnel (for the spring 1959 Oberlin Hoot recording): Neil Rosenberg, Mayne Smith, Chuck Crawford, John Schuler, Frank Miller, Phil Specht. According to Rosenberg the line-up may have been Mayne, banjo; John, bass; Neil, mandolin; Phil Specht, string bass; Frank and Charles, guitar. The tape source is unknown.

The Lorain County Strig Band demo was recorded in Oberlin, Ohio, at WOBC radio studio (the garage of Grey Gables). Engineers: Billy Crawford and Jerry Jentsch. This tape was dubbed from the 15 ips original. The first track may not be complete.

The recording of the Plum Creek Boys begins with a remnant of a previous recording on the tape that was not erased or taped over, in error. A sermon can be heard on occasion as well (from the incomplete erasure).

.

.

.

"Orange Blossom Special" - Plum Creek Boys. W. vocal. The first five songs (including this one) are a set. See
SR021
.

"I'll Fly Away" - Plum Creek Boys. Encore as concert-closing sing-along; four voices. Dedicated to "Lorain County String Band" (laughter). See
SR048
.

scopecontent.p:
Dubs of a concert ("hoot") presented by the Oberlin Folk Song Club, Oberlin, Ohio, held in Wilder Hall Auditorium. Ann Milovsoroff (Rosenberg's wife from 1961-1988) ordered her copy of the concert, and requested that Nancy omit 12 numbers, so these tapes hold only 36 of the original 48 numbers. Continued on
SR019
.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:11:55, Side 2: 00:17:40) : analog, 7 1/2 ips and 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: Special treatment was performed on Side 1 to splice segments at different speeds into one file at the correct speed. There was heavy distortion on the latter half of Side 1 and across Side 2, with speed fluctuations and wow on both sides, brief dropouts/gaps of silence, and static across both sides. There was high frequency loss on the latter half of Side 2.
The source tape identifies this recording as Side 2; the digital copy has been inadvertently identified as Side 1.
The recording was cut off about mid-way through the performance.
Vocal accompanied by banjo. Recorded in Indianapolis, Indiana, by Pat Dunford and Art Rosenbaum.
The source tape identifies this recording as Side 1; the digital copy has been inadvertently identified as Side 2.

did.unittitle:
Stanley Brothers at Indiana University,
February 19, 1966

scopecontent.p:
Recorded at Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana. Personnel: Ralph Stanley, banjo; Carter Stanley, guitar; Ginny Stamper, fiddle; George Shuffler, guitar. "Ginny" is pronounced with a hard "g." According to Neil Rosenberg (via email to the archivist) he was the brother of Art Stamper, and performed with the Stanley Brothers only twice. Ginny's full name may have been George Matthew Stamper. Continued on
SR138
.

Bill Monroe and His Blue Grass Boys at Bean Blossom,
July 17, 1966

scopecontent.p: Recorded at the afternoon show, Brown County Jamboree, Bean Blossom, Indiana. Personnel: Pete Rowan, guitar; Lamar Grier, banjo; Richard Green, fiddle; Jim Monroe, bass. According to Neil Rosenberg, he inadvertantly recorded the beginning of the Monroe show over a segment of the Stanley Brothers show (on his copy of the tape). Since he had taped the Stanley Brothers concert for the Indiana University Folksong Club and deposited the original recordings at the IU Archives of Traditional Music, the complete Stanley Brothers concert can be found there (ATM accession number 66-029-F).

Vendor digitization note: Special treatment performed on Side 2 to splice segments at different speeds into one file at the correct speed. Speed fluctuation on both sides. Vocal distortion on both sides. Abrupt transitions on Side 2. Side 2 was recorded at 7 1/2 ips.

Interview with Jimmy Martin,
probably 1968 or 1969

scopecontent.p: His early history, Tex Clymer, radio shows in the 1930s and 1940s, Cas Walker, joining Monroe, going to the Opry (getting up nerve)Monroe fires Mac Wiseman and hires Jimmy Martin. King recordings with Bobby Osborne, Detroit job, three years, from King to Victor, Sid Nathan, what happened to Victor's bluegrass, Flatt and Columbia, the record business.

Interview with Jimmy Martin for the Ralph Stanley Tape Club,
April 27, 1969
"Best Of Love" - first Decca gospel cut with Monroe, and "Poison Love," "Uncle Pen," "Golden Leaves. . ."
Working in Detroit - drew mail; sales
Winning radio contest - bluegrass not played by d.j. [disc jockey]
No bluegrass into colleges until "Hootenanny" TV show started
Pianos used in bluegrass - could be done
Drums used in bluegrass - rhythm necessary
His band: Bill Yates, string bass; Chris Warner, banjo; Vernon Derrick, fiddle and mandolin; Gloria Belle, girl singer
He recorded on the Shenandoah Valley Trio Columbia cuts

scopecontent.p: End of the interview. Further broadcast material listed PTO.
Radio show from Ypsilanti, Michigan, radio station

scopecontent.p: Dubs of transcription disc recordings of Grand Ole Opry radio shows, made for the U.S. Armed Forces Radio Service. The original recordings were made at the Ryman Auditorium, Nashville, Tennessee. The show numbers were assigned by the archivist for this tape only; each transcription disc had its own ID number (not identified at this time).

Interview with Sid Campbell at the Indian Springs Bluegrass Festival,
June 1, 1974

scopecontent.p: From the documentation for this recording: "Disc of Sid's involvement with Don/Red sessions on King, reminisenses, Sid on his recent recording, more on King recording, disc of Chuck Seitz (?) the King engineer, Dick Unteed and Jimmie Rodgers, changing musical taste/style, Unteed's record library, arrival of Polly Neubauer (BU employee, fired 7/75), disc of parking space at Festival." Recorded at the festival, in Hagerstown, Maryland, in Campbell's mobile camper. Campbell's wife Liz and one or two of their children were present. A separate cassette dub and transcription of the interview exist, possibly not with this collection.

did.unittitle:
Grand Ole Opry: Convention Week,
October 19, 1974

scopecontent.p: From the documentation (near verbatim, with a few extra words from the archivist for clarity): Various artists, beginning with the Osbornes. The first 30 minutes is from about 11-11:30 CDT, hosted by Porter Wagoner for 15 minutes, including Barbara Lea and Dolly Parton, then 15 minutes hosted by Roy Acuff, including Billy Grammer, Del Wood, Crook Brothers/McGee. The tape runs out, then picking it 15 minutes later, another square dance tune, Barbara Mandrell, and the reel runs out.

did.unittitle:
Grand Ole Opry: Convention Week,
October 19, 1974

scopecontent.p: From the documentation (near verbatim, with a few extra words from the archivist for clarity): hosted by Hank Snow, with Sam McGee playing some kind of railroad blues on guitar.

From the documentation (near verbatim, with a few extra words from the archivist for clarity): Beginning with 8:30 CDT, Roy Acuff, Dolly Parton, Osbornes - the break indicates the end of Carl's cassette. From About 9:05-9:35, and continuing a bit beyond that on another cassette, a segment hosted by Monroe. Monroe's guests include Justin "Tubbs," Willis Brothers, Carlisles. N.B. dedication of "Were You There" to Charlie in North Carolina. After Monroe, we get Roy Druskey.

did.unittitle: Digital surrogates of selected recordings in Series 3

did.physdesc: 786 sound files : digital (.aif, .mp3, .wav)

scopecontent.p: Audio files digitized by Brian Miksis from selected tapes. Includes high-resolution (aif or wav), medium-resolution CD pre-tagged (aif), and low-resolution pre-tagged (mp3) versions. Files form part of Miksis's "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive" digitization project.

arrangement.p: Files are located at the dc001 filepaths listed under "Documentation" throughout Series 3.

did.unittitle: Documentation of sound recordings and digitization
did.physdesc: 19 manuscript : digital (.docx, .pdf, .txt)

scopecontent.p: Additional documentation files, including documents explaining the digitization work of Miksis' "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive" project and his chronological index to recordings.

arrangement.p: The introduction and chronological index are located in the top data folder of dc001; other documentation files are located at the dc001 filepaths listed under "Documentation" throughout Series 3.
